Because volleyball is a rally sport, each play begins with a serve. To serve, a player must release the ball into the air and send it over the net by contacting it. The player must not be standing in-bounds when the ball is struck. 

	At the start of a game, it is determined which team will serve first using a coin toss. That team continues to serve until they lose a point/rally; at which point, control of the serve is transferred to the opposing team. 

	One of the most unique aspects of volleyball is the rotation system. There are six physical positions a player may occupy: front left (4), front middle (3), front right (2), back left (5), back middle (6), and back right (1). 

	Each time a team wins control of the serve, the players 'rotate' clockwise. This means that the player in position 2 (front right) rotates back to position 1 (back right), which is the serving position. 

	This system allows each player to rotate through the serving position. However, this system limits where each player can begin a rally. Moreover, it means each team is limited to three players who can attack from the front row at any given time. 

	Thus, the rotation system places significant constraints on each player's starting location for a given rally. As a result, high-level teams must plan their formations carefully in order to make the best use of specialized players.
